PUBLIC "-//Stanford University::Hoover Institution Archives//TEXT (US::CSt-H::::Roger A. Freeman Papers)//EN" "freemanr.sgm" converted from EAD 1.0 to 2002 by v1to02.cdl.xsl (2004-09-16).

titlepage.titleproper: Preliminary Inventory to the Roger A. Freeman Papers, 1950-1990
titlepage.publisher:
Hoover Institution Archives
Stanford University
Stanford, California
titlepage.p: © 1999 Hoover Institution Archives. All rights reserved.

did.head: Descriptive Summary

physdesc.label: Collection Size
physdesc.extent: 489 manuscript boxes, 4 oversize boxes, 1 card file box

did.abstract: Correspondence, memoranda, reports, studies, speeches and writings, printed matter, and slides, relating to governmental problems in the state of Washington, 1950-1955, fiscal problems of Bolivia, 1957, international economic development, taxation (federal, state, and local), intergovernmental relations in the United States, public and private education from lower schools to university in the United States and the Soviet Union, and the growth of American government.

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: Collection is stored off-site. It may be possible to have a limited number of boxes brought to the archives reading room for examination. A minimum of two days notice is required. Please contact the Hoover Institution Archives for further information.

The Hoover Institution Archives only allows access to copies of audiovisual items. To listen to sound recordings or to view videos or films during your visit, please contact the Archives at least two working days before your arrival. We will then advise you of the accessibility of the material you wish to see or hear. Please note that not all audiovisual material is immediately accessible.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: For copyright status, please contact the Hoover Institution Archives.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Roger A. Freeman Papers, [Box no.], Hoover Institution Archives.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical Note
bioghist.p: American economist; senior fellow, Hoover Institution on War, Revolution and Peace, 1962-1975; special assistant to President Richard M. Nixon, 1969-1970.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: Correspondence, memoranda, reports, studies, speeches and writings, printed matter, and slides, relating to governmental problems in the state of Washington, 1950-1955, fiscal problems of Bolivia, 1957, international economic development, taxation (federal, state, and local), intergovernmental relations in the United States, public and private education from lower schools to university in the United States and the Soviet Union, and the growth of American government.

Technical note on statistics, sources, reliability, etc.
Record of revenues, expenditures, debt in actual $, constant $,% GNP and NI, related to population and prices, per capita data. Tables & graphs 1902-72, 1952-72.
Private vs. public activities. Wagner's Law - Galbraith and his followers.
Government's role & needs in the XX century (last quarter) Protection and the service state, national priorities
Fiscal trends in war and peace (warfare and welfare)
Rates of increase in revenues, expenditures and debt in war periods (1913-22, 1940-44, 1950-53, 1965-69) and peace periods (1902-13, 1922-40, 1944-50, 1953-65, 1969-72)
Expenditures for national security (& other war-connected)
Tax levels in war and peace periods (federal)
Is federal employment growing? State & local employment and federal aid.
Record 1900-1950 (Fabricant) fed., state-local 1950 (53) 72. Defense & civilian services - relate to population, labor force, private employment, workload, etc. Administrative reorganization.
Salary trends (average wages, public & private), unionization, negotiation and strikes
Domestic activities of gernment (the Welfare State in Action)
Graphs, public and personal consumption, per capita, etc..
Rising income, why public goods are scarce, voluntary public activities, alternatives (tax credits)
Causes of crime and rise in crime rates
Retribution, deterrence, and rehabilitation (theories of criminal justice)
Attitudes of President, Congress, and public
Civilian vs. military judgment and control, military-industrial complex
Dangers to U.S. national security - countries, movements, trends. Time demands on President & Congress.
Benefits, costs & impact of governmental services
Standards, measure of benefits, Fiscal policy & growth, purpose of government (American politics tradition)
Projections of population & economy, revenue & expenditures

Conclusion - trend of expansion & effects on personal liberty. History - growing # and % dependence on government, concentration or power (monopoly), decline of voluntary action, growth of control - examples, regulatory action & guideposts & absence of opposition buy votes, Rome parallel - panem & circenses
Facing the Tax Bill (Many Unhappy Returns)
Tax burden & economic growth, what promotes economic growth?
1968 boost, 1969, 1971 cuts, outlook; state and local tax boosts
American tax structure, international comparisons, who pays the taxes?
Justification - sacrifice, ability theory, etc., redistribution, Blum-Kalven
Effect on incentives, Butters-Break, Soviet tax system
Merit & reward in market - social justice?
Other (dividend credit, hobby farming, split income - joint return, depreciation, etc.)
Problem areas (uniformity, fractional assessment, unequal distribution, restrictions, etc., land taxation)
Employment taxes - Social Security, Unemployment, Workman's Compensation, RR
The Shrinking Dollar (Inflation: the Hidden Tax)
History of value of $, effects of inflation (who bears the burden?), inflation in other countries, history - political effects

Size of the deficit and debt
Economic effects of the deficit and debt

Construction prices, housing and public works

Dispersal of power in the Constitution & centralizing trend
Fiscal capacity of state & local governments
Federal aid to state & local governments
General fiscal aid, tax redistribution, tax credits, in lieu payments

Permanently poor and social and economic mobility

What are the lags and why
Manpower, shortage of trained personnel, qualification at college entrance
Retarded children, "deprived" children, limits of educability - low IQs
Division of classes by ability and accomplishment, promotion
Yardsticks of educational accomplishment, voting, economic, report cards, tests, accreditation
